title: Aging society
prayerSummary: Give thanks for faithful elderly believers and pray they will share their faith with their peers.
Pray for Japanese churches to minister to the elderly, many of whom are lonely.
Pray for wisdom for the Japanese government and other leaders making decisions about issues such as healthcare, pensions, and community programs.
textBody: Celeste saw an elderly Japanese man fall out of his wheelchair on the sidewalk and helped him get home. She told him the address of her church, and later that week, he met her there. It was his first time in a church.

In 2023 more than 29% of Japan’s population is aged 65 and over.<sup>1</sup> This is among the highest in the world and is increasing as Japan’s population shrinks due to declining birthrates and a growing number of “lifelong singles.”

There are enormous long-term implications. Labor shortages have led to increased immigration and investment in artificial intelligence (AI). The healthcare and pension systems are under stress and many are concerned about the future.

A growing number of elderly people live alone and are becoming socially isolated. The number of those dying alone at home has also been increasing. Some districts are making efforts to promote the well-being of senior citizens through campaigns and events.

Christians are also trying to reach out. Some churches run exercise classes or host seniors’ lunches. Pastors visit elderly church members who are housebound or in hospitals. There are even elderly Christians who volunteer in nursing homes, seeking to befriend their peers.

photos.title: A large crowd of visitors at a prominent shrine in Kyoto (Fushimi Inari Taisha) on New Year's Day.
A gate at a Shinto shrine, called torii. Torii can be found at many places in Japan: city streets, staircases, forests, rivers, fields, and more.
A visitor at Meiji shrine bows before passing through the torii gate. A torii gate is seen as an entryway into sacred space.
A shrine on a small beach island (Aoshima) in Miyazaki prefecture.
A man prays at a local neighborhood shrine in Chiba prefecture.
Sensoji, a popular Buddhist temple in Tokyo.
A child and his guardian wave incense over themselves. This is a common purification or healing ritual at Buddhist temples.
A young man locating his omikuji, or fortune-telling paper.
Charms for protection and good luck called omamori on sale at a shrine.
A woman shops for a charm at a temple.
Visitors at Meiji shrine write prayer requests on wooden tablets called ema.
A child's prayer written on a prayer tablet at a shrine.
An elderly woman prays at the altar of a popular temple in Tokyo.
A woman drops coins in the offering box in front of a monkey statue, which is considered a patron of safety in childbirth.
Shrines often feature in important celebrations and rites of passage for Japanese families.
A couple takes wedding photographs at a shrine. In Japan, important life events are often celebrated at shrines.
Shichi-go-san is a festival in November celebrating children at the ages of seven, five, and three. It is often commemorated at shrines.
Summer festivals at shrines are often popular events for youth and young adults to attend with friends, family, or dates.
The Bon dance festival at Tsukiji Hongwanji temple.
